73 /** Construct an immediate of the given type from any numeric C++ type. */
74 // @{
75 Expr make_const(Type t, int64_t val);

113 /** Construct a boolean constant from a C++ boolean value.
114  * May also be a vector if width is given.
115  * It is not possible to coerce a C++ boolean to Expr because
116  * if we provide such a path then char objects can ambiguously
117  * be converted to Halide Expr or to std::string. The problem
118  * is that C++ does not have a real bool type - it is in fact
119  * close enough to char that C++ does not know how to distinguish them.
120  * make_bool is the explicit coercion. */
121 Expr make_bool(bool val, int lanes = 1);

130 Expr make_two(Type t);

145 /** Attempt to negate x without introducing new IR and without overflow.
146  * If it can't be done, return an undefined Expr. */

149 /** Coerce the two expressions to have the same type, using C-style
150  * casting rules. For the purposes of casting, a boolean type is
151  * UInt(1). We use the following procedure:
152  *
153  * If the types already match, do nothing.
154  *
155  * Then, if one type is a vector and the other is a scalar, the scalar
156  * is broadcast to match the vector width, and we continue.
157  *
158  * Then, if one type is floating-point and the other is not, the
159  * non-float is cast to the floating-point type, and we're done.
160  *
161  * Then, if both types are unsigned ints, the one with fewer bits is
162  * cast to match the one with more bits and we're done.
163  *
164  * Then, if both types are signed ints, the one with fewer bits is
165  * cast to match the one with more bits and we're done.
166  *
167  * Finally, if one type is an unsigned int and the other type is a signed
168  * int, both are cast to a signed int with the greater of the two
169  * bit-widths. For example, matching an Int(8) with a UInt(16) results
170  * in an Int(16).
171  *
172  */
173 void match_types(Expr &a, Expr &b);
174 
175 /** Asserts that both expressions are integer types and are either
176  * both signed or both unsigned. If one argument is scalar and the
177  * other a vector, the scalar is broadcasted to have the same number
178  * of lanes as the vector. If one expression is of narrower type than
179  * the other, it is widened to the bit width of the wider. */
180 void match_types_bitwise(Expr &a, Expr &b, const char *op_name);
181

186 Expr halide_erf(const Expr &a);

197 /** A builder to help create Exprs representing halide_buffer_t
198  * structs (e.g. foo.buffer) via calls to halide_buffer_init. Fill out
199  * the fields and then call build. The resulting Expr will be a call
200  * to halide_buffer_init with the struct members as arguments. If the
201  * buffer_memory field is undefined, it uses a call to alloca to make
202  * some stack memory for the buffer. If the shape_memory field is
203  * undefined, it similarly uses stack memory for the shape. If the
204  * shape_memory field is null, it uses the dim field already in the
205  * buffer. Other unitialized fields will take on a value of zero in
206  * the constructed buffer. */
207 struct BufferBuilder {
208  Expr buffer_memory, shape_memory;
209  Expr host, device, device_interface;
210  Type type;
211  int dimensions = 0;
212  std::vector<Expr> mins, extents, strides;
213  Expr host_dirty, device_dirty;
214  Expr build() const;
215 };

217 /** If e is a ramp expression with stride, default 1, return the base,
218  * otherwise undefined. */
219 Expr strided_ramp_base(const Expr &e, int stride = 1);
220 
221 /** Implementations of division and mod that are specific to Halide.
222  * Use these implementations; do not use native C division or mod to
223  * simplify Halide expressions. Halide division and modulo satisify
224  * the Euclidean definition of division for integers a and b:
225  *
226  /code
227  when b != 0, (a/b)*b + a%b = a
228  0 <= a%b < |b|
229  /endcode
230  *
231  * Additionally, mod by zero returns zero, and div by zero returns
232  * zero. This makes mod and div total functions.
233  */
234 // @{
235 template<typename T>
236 inline T mod_imp(T a, T b) {
237  Type t = type_of<T>();
238  if (!t.is_float() && b == 0) {
239  return 0;
240  } else if (t.is_int()) {
241  int64_t ia = a;
242  int64_t ib = b;
243  int64_t a_neg = ia >> 63;
244  int64_t b_neg = ib >> 63;
245  int64_t b_zero = (ib == 0) ? -1 : 0;
246  ia -= a_neg;
247  int64_t r = ia % (ib | b_zero);
248  r += (a_neg & ((ib ^ b_neg) + ~b_neg));
249  r &= ~b_zero;
250  return r;
251  } else {
252  return a % b;
253  }
254 }
255 
256 template<typename T>
257 inline T div_imp(T a, T b) {
258  Type t = type_of<T>();
259  if (!t.is_float() && b == 0) {
260  return (T)0;
261  } else if (t.is_int()) {
262  // Do it as 64-bit
263  int64_t ia = a;
264  int64_t ib = b;
265  int64_t a_neg = ia >> 63;
266  int64_t b_neg = ib >> 63;
267  int64_t b_zero = (ib == 0) ? -1 : 0;
268  ib -= b_zero;
269  ia -= a_neg;
270  int64_t q = ia / ib;
271  q += a_neg & (~b_neg - b_neg);
272  q &= ~b_zero;
273  return (T)q;
274  } else {
275  return a / b;
276  }
277 }
278 // @}
279 
280 // Special cases for float, double.
281 template<>
282 inline float mod_imp<float>(float a, float b) {
283  float f = a - b * (floorf(a / b));
284  // The remainder has the same sign as b.
285  return f;
286 }
287 template<>
288 inline double mod_imp<double>(double a, double b) {
289  double f = a - b * (std::floor(a / b));
290  return f;
291 }
292 
293 template<>
294 inline float div_imp<float>(float a, float b) {
295  return a / b;
296 }
297 template<>
298 inline double div_imp<double>(double a, double b) {
299  return a / b;
300 }

311 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE void collect_print_args(std::vector<Expr> &args) {

314 template<typename... Args>
315 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE void collect_print_args(std::vector<Expr> &args, const char *arg, Args &&...more_args) {
316  args.emplace_back(std::string(arg));
317  collect_print_args(args, std::forward<Args>(more_args)...);
318 }
319 
320 template<typename... Args>
321 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE void collect_print_args(std::vector<Expr> &args, Expr arg, Args &&...more_args) {
322  args.push_back(std::move(arg));
323  collect_print_args(args, std::forward<Args>(more_args)...);
324 }

330 /** Compute widen(a) + widen(b). The result is always signed. */
331 Expr widening_add(Expr a, Expr b);
332 /** Compute widen(a) * widen(b). a and b may have different signedness. */
333 Expr widening_mul(Expr a, Expr b);
334 /** Compute widen(a) - widen(b). The result is always signed. */
335 Expr widening_sub(Expr a, Expr b);

337 Expr widening_shift_left(Expr a, Expr b);
338 /** Compute widen(a) >> b. */
339 Expr widening_shift_right(Expr a, Expr b);

341 /** Compute saturating_add(a, (1 >> min(b, 0)) / 2) << b. When b is positive
342  * indicating a left shift, the rounding term is zero. */
343 Expr rounding_shift_left(Expr a, Expr b);
344 /** Compute saturating_add(a, (1 << max(b, 0)) / 2) >> b. When b is negative
345  * indicating a left shift, the rounding term is zero. */
346 Expr rounding_shift_right(Expr a, Expr b);
347 
348 /** Compute saturating_narrow(widen(a) + widen(b)) */
349 Expr saturating_add(Expr a, Expr b);
350 /** Compute saturating_narrow(widen(a) - widen(b)) */
351 Expr saturating_sub(Expr a, Expr b);
352 
353 /** Compute narrow((widen(a) + widen(b)) / 2) */
354 Expr halving_add(Expr a, Expr b);
355 /** Compute narrow((widen(a) + widen(b) + 1) / 2) */
356 Expr rounding_halving_add(Expr a, Expr b);
357 /** Compute narrow((widen(a) - widen(b)) / 2) */
358 Expr halving_sub(Expr a, Expr b);
359 /** Compute narrow((widen(a) - widen(b) + 1) / 2) */
360 Expr rounding_halving_sub(Expr a, Expr b);

407 /** Return the negative of the argument. Does no type casting, so more
408  * formally: return that number which when added to the original,
409  * yields zero of the same type. For unsigned integers the negative is
410  * still an unsigned integer. E.g. in UInt(8), the negative of 56 is
411  * 200, because 56 + 200 == 0 */
412 Expr operator-(Expr a);
413

415  * without changing its type. This casts the second argument to match
416  * the type of the first. */
417 Expr &operator-=(Expr &a, Expr b);

437 
438 /** Return the ratio of two expressions, doing any necessary type
439  * coercion using \ref Internal::match_types. Note that integer
440  * division in Halide is not the same as integer division in C-like
441  * languages in two ways.
442  *
443  * First, signed integer division in Halide rounds according to the
444  * sign of the denominator. This means towards minus infinity for
445  * positive denominators, and towards positive infinity for negative
446  * denominators. This is unlike C, which rounds towards zero. This
447  * decision ensures that upsampling expressions like f(x/2, y/2) don't
448  * have funny discontinuities when x and y cross zero.
449  *
450  * Second, division by zero returns zero instead of faulting. For
451  * types where overflow is defined behavior, division of the largest
452  * negative signed integer by -1 returns the larged negative signed
453  * integer for the type (i.e. it wraps). This ensures that a division
454  * operation can never have a side-effect, which is helpful in Halide
455  * because scheduling directives can expand the domain of computation
456  * of a Func, potentially introducing new zero-division.
457  */
458 Expr operator/(Expr a, Expr b);
459 
460 /** Modify the first expression to be the ratio of two expressions,
461  * without changing its type. This casts the second argument to match
462  * the type of the first. Note that signed integer division in Halide
463  * rounds towards minus infinity, unlike C, which rounds towards
464  * zero. */
465 Expr &operator/=(Expr &a, Expr b);
466 
467 /** Divides an expression by a constant integer. Coerces the type
468  * of the integer to match the type of the expression. Errors if the
469  * integer cannot be represented in the type of the expression. */
470 Expr operator/(Expr a, int b);
471 
472 /** Divides a constant integer by an expression. Coerces the type
473  * of the integer to match the type of the expression. Errors if the
474  * integer cannot be represented in the type of the expression. */
475 Expr operator/(int a, Expr b);
476 
477 /** Return the first argument reduced modulo the second, doing any
478  * necessary type coercion using \ref Internal::match_types. There are
479  * two key differences between C-like languages and Halide for the
480  * modulo operation, which complement the way division works.
481  *
482  * First, the result is never negative, so x % 2 is always zero or
483  * one, unlike in C-like languages. x % -2 is equivalent, and is also
484  * always zero or one. Second, mod by zero evaluates to zero (unlike
485  * in C, where it faults). This makes modulo, like division, a
486  * side-effect-free operation. */
487 Expr operator%(Expr a, Expr b);
488 
489 /** Mods an expression by a constant integer. Coerces the type
490  * of the integer to match the type of the expression. Errors if the
491  * integer cannot be represented in the type of the expression. */
492 Expr operator%(Expr a, int b);
493 
494 /** Mods a constant integer by an expression. Coerces the type
495  * of the integer to match the type of the expression. Errors if the
496  * integer cannot be represented in the type of the expression. */
497 Expr operator%(int a, Expr b);
498 
499 /** Return a boolean expression that tests whether the first argument
500  * is greater than the second, after doing any necessary type coercion
501  * using \ref Internal::match_types */
502 Expr operator>(Expr a, Expr b);

506  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable in that
507  * type. */
508 Expr operator>(Expr a, int b);

512  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable in that
513  * type. */
514 Expr operator>(int a, Expr b);
515

519 Expr operator<(Expr a, Expr b);

530  * type. */
531 Expr operator<(int a, Expr b);

589 /** Return a boolean expression that tests whether an expression is
590  * not equal to a constant integer. Coerces the integer to the type of
591  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable in that
592  * type. */
593 Expr operator!=(Expr a, int b);
594 
595 /** Return a boolean expression that tests whether a constant integer
596  * is not equal to an expression. Coerces the integer to the type of
597  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable in that
598  * type. */
599 Expr operator!=(int a, Expr b);
600 
601 /** Returns the logical and of the two arguments */
602 Expr operator&&(Expr a, Expr b);
603 
604 /** Logical and of an Expr and a bool. Either returns the Expr or an
605  * Expr representing false, depending on the bool. */
606 // @{
607 Expr operator&&(Expr a, bool b);
608 Expr operator&&(bool a, Expr b);
609 // @}
610 
611 /** Returns the logical or of the two arguments */
612 Expr operator||(Expr a, Expr b);
613 
614 /** Logical or of an Expr and a bool. Either returns the Expr or an
615  * Expr representing true, depending on the bool. */
616 // @{
617 Expr operator||(Expr a, bool b);
618 Expr operator||(bool a, Expr b);
619 // @}
620 
621 /** Returns the logical not the argument */
622 Expr operator!(Expr a);
623 
624 /** Returns an expression representing the greater of the two
625  * arguments, after doing any necessary type coercion using
626  * \ref Internal::match_types. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms
627  * (with the exception of integer types on x86 without SSE4). */
628 Expr max(Expr a, Expr b);
629 
630 /** Returns an expression representing the greater of an expression
631  * and a constant integer. The integer is coerced to the type of the
632  * expression. Errors if the integer is not representable as that
633  * type. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms (with the exception of
634  * integer types on x86 without SSE4). */
635 Expr max(Expr a, int b);
636 
637 /** Returns an expression representing the greater of a constant
638  * integer and an expression. The integer is coerced to the type of
639  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable as that
640  * type. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms (with the exception of
641  * integer types on x86 without SSE4). */
642 Expr max(int a, Expr b);
643 
644 inline Expr max(float a, Expr b) {
645  return max(Expr(a), std::move(b));
646 }
647 inline Expr max(Expr a, float b) {
648  return max(std::move(a), Expr(b));
649 }
650 
651 /** Returns an expression representing the greater of an expressions
652  * vector, after doing any necessary type coersion using
653  * \ref Internal::match_types. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms
654  * (with the exception of integer types on x86 without SSE4).
655  * The expressions are folded from right ie. max(.., max(.., ..)).
656  * The arguments can be any mix of types but must all be convertible to Expr. */
657 template<typename A, typename B, typename C, typename... Rest,
658  typename std::enable_if<Halide::Internal::all_are_convertible<Expr, Rest...>::value>::type * = nullptr>
659 inline Expr max(A &&a, B &&b, C &&c, Rest &&...rest) {
660  return max(std::forward<A>(a), max(std::forward<B>(b), std::forward<C>(c), std::forward<Rest>(rest)...));
661 }
662 
663 Expr min(Expr a, Expr b);
664 
665 /** Returns an expression representing the lesser of an expression
666  * and a constant integer. The integer is coerced to the type of the
667  * expression. Errors if the integer is not representable as that
668  * type. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms (with the exception of
669  * integer types on x86 without SSE4). */
670 Expr min(Expr a, int b);
671 
672 /** Returns an expression representing the lesser of a constant
673  * integer and an expression. The integer is coerced to the type of
674  * the expression. Errors if the integer is not representable as that
675  * type. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms (with the exception of
676  * integer types on x86 without SSE4). */
677 Expr min(int a, Expr b);
678 
679 inline Expr min(float a, Expr b) {
680  return min(Expr(a), std::move(b));
681 }
682 inline Expr min(Expr a, float b) {
683  return min(std::move(a), Expr(b));
684 }
685 
686 /** Returns an expression representing the lesser of an expressions
687  * vector, after doing any necessary type coersion using
688  * \ref Internal::match_types. Vectorizes cleanly on most platforms
689  * (with the exception of integer types on x86 without SSE4).
690  * The expressions are folded from right ie. min(.., min(.., ..)).
691  * The arguments can be any mix of types but must all be convertible to Expr. */
692 template<typename A, typename B, typename C, typename... Rest,
693  typename std::enable_if<Halide::Internal::all_are_convertible<Expr, Rest...>::value>::type * = nullptr>
694 inline Expr min(A &&a, B &&b, C &&c, Rest &&...rest) {
695  return min(std::forward<A>(a), min(std::forward<B>(b), std::forward<C>(c), std::forward<Rest>(rest)...));
696 }
697 
698 /** Operators on floats treats those floats as Exprs. Making these
699  * explicit prevents implicit float->int casts that might otherwise
700  * occur. */
701 // @{
702 inline Expr operator+(Expr a, float b) {
703  return std::move(a) + Expr(b);
704 }
705 inline Expr operator+(float a, Expr b) {
706  return Expr(a) + std::move(b);
707 }
708 inline Expr operator-(Expr a, float b) {
709  return std::move(a) - Expr(b);
710 }
711 inline Expr operator-(float a, Expr b) {
712  return Expr(a) - std::move(b);
713 }
714 inline Expr operator*(Expr a, float b) {
715  return std::move(a) * Expr(b);
716 }
717 inline Expr operator*(float a, Expr b) {
718  return Expr(a) * std::move(b);
719 }
720 inline Expr operator/(Expr a, float b) {
721  return std::move(a) / Expr(b);
722 }
723 inline Expr operator/(float a, Expr b) {
724  return Expr(a) / std::move(b);
725 }
726 inline Expr operator%(Expr a, float b) {
727  return std::move(a) % Expr(b);
728 }
729 inline Expr operator%(float a, Expr b) {
730  return Expr(a) % std::move(b);
731 }
732 inline Expr operator>(Expr a, float b) {
733  return std::move(a) > Expr(b);
734 }
735 inline Expr operator>(float a, Expr b) {
736  return Expr(a) > std::move(b);
737 }
738 inline Expr operator<(Expr a, float b) {
739  return std::move(a) < Expr(b);
740 }
741 inline Expr operator<(float a, Expr b) {
742  return Expr(a) < std::move(b);
743 }
744 inline Expr operator>=(Expr a, float b) {
745  return std::move(a) >= Expr(b);
746 }
747 inline Expr operator>=(float a, Expr b) {
748  return Expr(a) >= std::move(b);
749 }
750 inline Expr operator<=(Expr a, float b) {
751  return std::move(a) <= Expr(b);
752 }
753 inline Expr operator<=(float a, Expr b) {
754  return Expr(a) <= std::move(b);
755 }
756 inline Expr operator==(Expr a, float b) {
757  return std::move(a) == Expr(b);
758 }
759 inline Expr operator==(float a, Expr b) {
760  return Expr(a) == std::move(b);
761 }
762 inline Expr operator!=(Expr a, float b) {
763  return std::move(a) != Expr(b);
764 }
765 inline Expr operator!=(float a, Expr b) {
766  return Expr(a) != std::move(b);
767 }
768 // @}
769 
770 /** Clamps an expression to lie within the given bounds. The bounds
771  * are type-cast to match the expression. Vectorizes as well as min/max. */
772 Expr clamp(Expr a, const Expr &min_val, const Expr &max_val);
773 
774 /** Returns the absolute value of a signed integer or floating-point
775  * expression. Vectorizes cleanly. Unlike in C, abs of a signed
776  * integer returns an unsigned integer of the same bit width. This
777  * means that abs of the most negative integer doesn't overflow. */
778 Expr abs(Expr a);
779 
780 /** Return the absolute difference between two values. Vectorizes
781  * cleanly. Returns an unsigned value of the same bit width. There are
782  * various ways to write this yourself, but they contain numerous
783  * gotchas and don't always compile to good code, so use this
784  * instead. */
785 Expr absd(Expr a, Expr b);
786 
787 /** Returns an expression similar to the ternary operator in C, except
788  * that it always evaluates all arguments. If the first argument is
789  * true, then return the second, else return the third. Typically
790  * vectorizes cleanly, but benefits from SSE41 or newer on x86. */
791 Expr select(Expr condition, Expr true_value, Expr false_value);
792 
793 /** A multi-way variant of select similar to a switch statement in C,
794  * which can accept multiple conditions and values in pairs. Evaluates
795  * to the first value for which the condition is true. Returns the
796  * final value if all conditions are false. */
797 template<typename... Args,
798  typename std::enable_if<Halide::Internal::all_are_convertible<Expr, Args...>::value>::type * = nullptr>
799 inline Expr select(Expr c0, Expr v0, Expr c1, Expr v1, Args &&...args) {
800  return select(std::move(c0), std::move(v0), select(std::move(c1), std::move(v1), std::forward<Args>(args)...));
801 }
802 
803 /** Equivalent of ternary select(), but taking/returning tuples. If the condition is
804  * a Tuple, it must match the size of the true and false Tuples. */
805 // @{
806 Tuple tuple_select(const Tuple &condition, const Tuple &true_value, const Tuple &false_value);
807 Tuple tuple_select(const Expr &condition, const Tuple &true_value, const Tuple &false_value);
808 // @}
809 
810 /** Equivalent of multiway select(), but taking/returning tuples. If the condition is
811  * a Tuple, it must match the size of the true and false Tuples. */
812 // @{
813 template<typename... Args>
814 inline Tuple tuple_select(const Tuple &c0, const Tuple &v0, const Tuple &c1, const Tuple &v1, Args &&...args) {
815  return tuple_select(c0, v0, tuple_select(c1, v1, std::forward<Args>(args)...));
816 }
817 
818 template<typename... Args>
819 inline Tuple tuple_select(const Expr &c0, const Tuple &v0, const Expr &c1, const Tuple &v1, Args &&...args) {
820  return tuple_select(c0, v0, tuple_select(c1, v1, std::forward<Args>(args)...));
821 }
822 // @}
823 
824 /** Oftentimes we want to pack a list of expressions with the same type
825  * into a channel dimension, e.g.,
826  * img(x, y, c) = select(c == 0, 100, // Red
827  * c == 1, 50, // Green
828  * 25); // Blue
829  * This is tedious when the list is long. The following function
830  * provide convinent syntax that allow one to write:
831  * img(x, y, c) = mux(c, {100, 50, 25});
832  *
833  * As with the select equivalent, if the first argument (the index) is
834  * out of range, the expression evaluates to the last value.
835  */
836 // @{
837 Expr mux(const Expr &id, const std::initializer_list<Expr> &values);
838 Expr mux(const Expr &id, const std::vector<Expr> &values);
839 Expr mux(const Expr &id, const Tuple &values);
840 // @}
841 
842 /** Return the sine of a floating-point expression. If the argument is
843  * not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not vectorize
844  * well. */
845 Expr sin(Expr x);
846 
847 /** Return the arcsine of a floating-point expression. If the argument
848  * is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not vectorize
849  * well. */
850 Expr asin(Expr x);
851 
852 /** Return the cosine of a floating-point expression. If the argument
853  * is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not vectorize
854  * well. */
855 Expr cos(Expr x);
856 
857 /** Return the arccosine of a floating-point expression. If the
858  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not
859  * vectorize well. */
860 Expr acos(Expr x);
861 
862 /** Return the tangent of a floating-point expression. If the argument
863  * is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not vectorize
864  * well. */
865 Expr tan(Expr x);
866

868  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not
869  * vectorize well. */
870 Expr atan(Expr x);
871 
872 /** Return the angle of a floating-point gradient. If the argument is
873  * not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not vectorize
874  * well. */
875 Expr atan2(Expr y, Expr x);
876 
877 /** Return the hyperbolic sine of a floating-point expression. If the
878  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does not
879  * vectorize well. */
880 Expr sinh(Expr x);

882 /** Return the hyperbolic arcsinhe of a floating-point expression. If
883  * the argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does
884  * not vectorize well. */
885 Expr asinh(Expr x);
886 
887 /** Return the hyperbolic cosine of a floating-point expression. If
888  * the argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does
889  * not vectorize well. */
890 Expr cosh(Expr x);
891

893  * If the argument is not floating-point, it is cast to
894  * Float(32). Does not vectorize well. */
895 Expr acosh(Expr x);

898  * the argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Does
899  * not vectorize well. */
900 Expr tanh(Expr x);
901 
902 /** Return the hyperbolic arctangent of a floating-point expression.
903  * If the argument is not floating-point, it is cast to
904  * Float(32). Does not vectorize well. */
905 Expr atanh(Expr x);
906 
907 /** Return the square root of a floating-point expression. If the
908  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). Typically
909  * vectorizes cleanly. */
910 Expr sqrt(Expr x);
911 
912 /** Return the square root of the sum of the squares of two
913  * floating-point expressions. If the argument is not floating-point,
914  * it is cast to Float(32). Vectorizes cleanly. */
915 Expr hypot(const Expr &x, const Expr &y);
916 
917 /** Return the exponential of a floating-point expression. If the
918  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). For
919  * Float(64) arguments, this calls the system exp function, and does
920  * not vectorize well. For Float(32) arguments, this function is
921  * vectorizable, does the right thing for extremely small or extremely
922  * large inputs, and is accurate up to the last bit of the
923  * mantissa. Vectorizes cleanly. */
924 Expr exp(Expr x);
925 
926 /** Return the logarithm of a floating-point expression. If the
927  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). For
928  * Float(64) arguments, this calls the system log function, and does
929  * not vectorize well. For Float(32) arguments, this function is
930  * vectorizable, does the right thing for inputs <= 0 (returns -inf or
931  * nan), and is accurate up to the last bit of the
932  * mantissa. Vectorizes cleanly. */
933 Expr log(Expr x);
934 
935 /** Return one floating point expression raised to the power of
936  * another. The type of the result is given by the type of the first
937  * argument. If the first argument is not a floating-point type, it is
938  * cast to Float(32). For Float(32), cleanly vectorizable, and
939  * accurate up to the last few bits of the mantissa. Gets worse when
940  * approaching overflow. Vectorizes cleanly. */
941 Expr pow(Expr x, Expr y);
942 
943 /** Evaluate the error function erf. Only available for
944  * Float(32). Accurate up to the last three bits of the
945  * mantissa. Vectorizes cleanly. */
946 Expr erf(const Expr &x);
947 
948 /** Fast vectorizable approximation to some trigonometric functions for Float(32).
949  * Absolute approximation error is less than 1e-5. */
950 // @{
951 Expr fast_sin(const Expr &x);
952 Expr fast_cos(const Expr &x);
953 // @}
954 
955 /** Fast approximate cleanly vectorizable log for Float(32). Returns
956  * nonsense for x <= 0.0f. Accurate up to the last 5 bits of the
957  * mantissa. Vectorizes cleanly. */
958 Expr fast_log(const Expr &x);
959 
960 /** Fast approximate cleanly vectorizable exp for Float(32). Returns
961  * nonsense for inputs that would overflow or underflow. Typically
962  * accurate up to the last 5 bits of the mantissa. Gets worse when
963  * approaching overflow. Vectorizes cleanly. */
964 Expr fast_exp(const Expr &x);
965 
966 /** Fast approximate cleanly vectorizable pow for Float(32). Returns
967  * nonsense for x < 0.0f. Accurate up to the last 5 bits of the
968  * mantissa for typical exponents. Gets worse when approaching
969  * overflow. Vectorizes cleanly. */
970 Expr fast_pow(Expr x, Expr y);
971 
972 /** Fast approximate inverse for Float(32). Corresponds to the rcpps
973  * instruction on x86, and the vrecpe instruction on ARM. Vectorizes
974  * cleanly. Note that this can produce slightly different results
975  * across different implementations of the same architecture (e.g. AMD vs Intel),
976  * even when strict_float is enabled. */
977 Expr fast_inverse(Expr x);
978 
979 /** Fast approximate inverse square root for Float(32). Corresponds to
980  * the rsqrtps instruction on x86, and the vrsqrte instruction on
981  * ARM. Vectorizes cleanly. Note that this can produce slightly different results
982  * across different implementations of the same architecture (e.g. AMD vs Intel),
983  * even when strict_float is enabled. */
984 Expr fast_inverse_sqrt(Expr x);
985 
986 /** Return the greatest whole number less than or equal to a
987  * floating-point expression. If the argument is not floating-point,
988  * it is cast to Float(32). The return value is still in floating
989  * point, despite being a whole number. Vectorizes cleanly. */
990 Expr floor(Expr x);
991 
992 /** Return the least whole number greater than or equal to a
993  * floating-point expression. If the argument is not floating-point,
994  * it is cast to Float(32). The return value is still in floating
995  * point, despite being a whole number. Vectorizes cleanly. */
996 Expr ceil(Expr x);
997 
998 /** Return the whole number closest to a floating-point expression. If the
999  * argument is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). The return value
1000  * is still in floating point, despite being a whole number. On ties, we
1001  * follow IEEE754 conventions and round to the nearest even number. Vectorizes
1002  * cleanly. */
1003 Expr round(Expr x);
1004 
1005 /** Return the integer part of a floating-point expression. If the argument is
1006  * not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). The return value is still in
1007  * floating point, despite being a whole number. Vectorizes cleanly. */
1008 Expr trunc(Expr x);
1009 
1010 /** Returns true if the argument is a Not a Number (NaN). Requires a
1011  * floating point argument. Vectorizes cleanly.
1012  * Note that the Expr passed in will be evaluated in strict_float mode,
1013  * regardless of whether strict_float mode is enabled in the current Target. */
1014 Expr is_nan(Expr x);
1015 
1016 /** Returns true if the argument is Inf or -Inf. Requires a
1017  * floating point argument. Vectorizes cleanly.
1018  * Note that the Expr passed in will be evaluated in strict_float mode,
1019  * regardless of whether strict_float mode is enabled in the current Target. */
1020 Expr is_inf(Expr x);
1021 
1022 /** Returns true if the argument is a finite value (ie, neither NaN nor Inf).
1023  * Requires a floating point argument. Vectorizes cleanly.
1024  * Note that the Expr passed in will be evaluated in strict_float mode,
1025  * regardless of whether strict_float mode is enabled in the current Target. */
1026 Expr is_finite(Expr x);
1027 
1028 /** Return the fractional part of a floating-point expression. If the argument
1029  * is not floating-point, it is cast to Float(32). The return value has the
1030  * same sign as the original expression. Vectorizes cleanly. */
1031 Expr fract(const Expr &x);
1032 
1033 /** Reinterpret the bits of one value as another type. */
1034 Expr reinterpret(Type t, Expr e);
1035 
1036 template<typename T>
1037 Expr reinterpret(Expr e) {
1038  return reinterpret(type_of<T>(), e);
1039 }
1040 
1041 /** Return the bitwise and of two expressions (which need not have the
1042  * same type). The result type is the wider of the two expressions.
1043  * Only integral types are allowed and both expressions must be signed
1044  * or both must be unsigned. */
1045 Expr operator&(Expr x, Expr y);
1046 
1047 /** Return the bitwise and of an expression and an integer. The type
1048  * of the result is the type of the expression argument. */
1049 // @{
1050 Expr operator&(Expr x, int y);
1051 Expr operator&(int x, Expr y);
1052 // @}
1053 
1054 /** Return the bitwise or of two expressions (which need not have the
1055  * same type). The result type is the wider of the two expressions.
1056  * Only integral types are allowed and both expressions must be signed
1057  * or both must be unsigned. */
1058 Expr operator|(Expr x, Expr y);
1059 
1060 /** Return the bitwise or of an expression and an integer. The type of
1061  * the result is the type of the expression argument. */
1062 // @{
1063 Expr operator|(Expr x, int y);
1064 Expr operator|(int x, Expr y);
1065 // @}
1066 
1067 /** Return the bitwise xor of two expressions (which need not have the
1068  * same type). The result type is the wider of the two expressions.
1069  * Only integral types are allowed and both expressions must be signed
1070  * or both must be unsigned. */
1071 Expr operator^(Expr x, Expr y);
1072 
1073 /** Return the bitwise xor of an expression and an integer. The type
1074  * of the result is the type of the expression argument. */
1075 // @{
1076 Expr operator^(Expr x, int y);
1077 Expr operator^(int x, Expr y);
1078 // @}
1079 
1080 /** Return the bitwise not of an expression. */
1081 Expr operator~(Expr x);
1082 
1083 /** Shift the bits of an integer value left. This is actually less
1084  * efficient than multiplying by 2^n, because Halide's optimization
1085  * passes understand multiplication, and will compile it to
1086  * shifting. This operator is only for if you really really need bit
1087  * shifting (e.g. because the exponent is a run-time parameter). The
1088  * type of the result is equal to the type of the first argument. Both
1089  * arguments must have integer type. */
1090 // @{
1091 Expr operator<<(Expr x, Expr y);
1092 Expr operator<<(Expr x, int y);
1093 // @}
1094 
1095 /** Shift the bits of an integer value right. Does sign extension for
1096  * signed integers. This is less efficient than dividing by a power of
1097  * two. Halide's definition of division (always round to negative
1098  * infinity) means that all divisions by powers of two get compiled to
1099  * bit-shifting, and Halide's optimization routines understand
1100  * division and can work with it. The type of the result is equal to
1101  * the type of the first argument. Both arguments must have integer
1102  * type. */
1103 // @{
1104 Expr operator>>(Expr x, Expr y);
1105 Expr operator>>(Expr x, int y);
1106 // @}
1107 
1108 /** Linear interpolate between the two values according to a weight.
1109  * \param zero_val The result when weight is 0
1110  * \param one_val The result when weight is 1
1111  * \param weight The interpolation amount
1112  *
1113  * Both zero_val and one_val must have the same type. All types are
1114  * supported, including bool.
1115  *
1116  * The weight is treated as its own type and must be float or an
1117  * unsigned integer type. It is scaled to the bit-size of the type of
1118  * x and y if they are integer, or converted to float if they are
1119  * float. Integer weights are converted to float via division by the
1120  * full-range value of the weight's type. Floating-point weights used
1121  * to interpolate between integer values must be between 0.0f and
1122  * 1.0f, and an error may be signaled if it is not provably so. (clamp
1123  * operators can be added to provide proof. Currently an error is only
1124  * signalled for constant weights.)
1125  *
1126  * For integer linear interpolation, out of range values cannot be
1127  * represented. In particular, weights that are conceptually less than
1128  * 0 or greater than 1.0 are not representable. As such the result is
1129  * always between x and y (inclusive of course). For lerp with
1130  * floating-point values and floating-point weight, the full range of
1131  * a float is valid, however underflow and overflow can still occur.
1132  *
1133  * Ordering is not required between zero_val and one_val:
1134  * lerp(42, 69, .5f) == lerp(69, 42, .5f) == 56
1135  *
1136  * Results for integer types are for exactly rounded arithmetic. As
1137  * such, there are cases where 16-bit and float differ because 32-bit
1138  * floating-point (float) does not have enough precision to produce
1139  * the exact result. (Likely true for 32-bit integer
1140  * vs. double-precision floating-point as well.)
1141  *
1142  * At present, double precision and 64-bit integers are not supported.
1143  *
1144  * Generally, lerp will vectorize as if it were an operation on a type
1145  * twice the bit size of the inferred type for x and y.
1146  *
1147  * Some examples:
1148  * \code
1149  *
1150  * // Since Halide does not have direct type delcarations, casts
1151  * // below are used to indicate the types of the parameters.
1152  * // Such casts not required or expected in actual code where types
1153  * // are inferred.
1154  *
1155  * lerp(cast<float>(x), cast<float>(y), cast<float>(w)) ->
1156  * x * (1.0f - w) + y * w
1157  *
1158  * lerp(cast<uint8_t>(x), cast<uint8_t>(y), cast<uint8_t>(w)) ->
1159  * cast<uint8_t>(cast<uint8_t>(x) * (1.0f - cast<uint8_t>(w) / 255.0f) +
1160  * cast<uint8_t>(y) * cast<uint8_t>(w) / 255.0f + .5f)
1161  *
1162  * // Note addition in Halide promoted uint8_t + int8_t to int16_t already,
1163  * // the outer cast is added for clarity.
1164  * lerp(cast<uint8_t>(x), cast<int8_t>(y), cast<uint8_t>(w)) ->
1165  * cast<int16_t>(cast<uint8_t>(x) * (1.0f - cast<uint8_t>(w) / 255.0f) +
1166  * cast<int8_t>(y) * cast<uint8_t>(w) / 255.0f + .5f)
1167  *
1168  * lerp(cast<int8_t>(x), cast<int8_t>(y), cast<float>(w)) ->
1169  * cast<int8_t>(cast<int8_t>(x) * (1.0f - cast<float>(w)) +
1170  * cast<int8_t>(y) * cast<uint8_t>(w))
1171  *
1172  * \endcode
1173  * */
1174 Expr lerp(Expr zero_val, Expr one_val, Expr weight);
1175 
1176 /** Count the number of set bits in an expression. */
1177 Expr popcount(Expr x);
1178 
1179 /** Count the number of leading zero bits in an expression. If the expression is
1180  * zero, the result is the number of bits in the type. */
1181 Expr count_leading_zeros(Expr x);
1182 
1183 /** Count the number of trailing zero bits in an expression. If the expression is
1184  * zero, the result is the number of bits in the type. */
1185 Expr count_trailing_zeros(Expr x);
1186 
1187 /** Divide two integers, rounding towards zero. This is the typical
1188  * behavior of most hardware architectures, which differs from
1189  * Halide's division operator, which is Euclidean (rounds towards
1190  * -infinity). Will throw a runtime error if y is zero, or if y is -1
1191  * and x is the minimum signed integer. */
1192 Expr div_round_to_zero(Expr x, Expr y);
1193 
1194 /** Compute the remainder of dividing two integers, when division is
1195  * rounding toward zero. This is the typical behavior of most hardware
1196  * architectures, which differs from Halide's mod operator, which is
1197  * Euclidean (produces the remainder when division rounds towards
1198  * -infinity). Will throw a runtime error if y is zero. */
1199 Expr mod_round_to_zero(Expr x, Expr y);
1200 
1201 /** Return a random variable representing a uniformly distributed
1202  * float in the half-open interval [0.0f, 1.0f). For random numbers of
1203  * other types, use lerp with a random float as the last parameter.
1204  *
1205  * Optionally takes a seed.
1206  *
1207  * Note that:
1208  \code
1209  Expr x = random_float();
1210  Expr y = x + x;
1211  \endcode
1212  *
1213  * is very different to
1214  *
1215  \code
1216  Expr y = random_float() + random_float();
1217  \endcode
1218  *
1219  * The first doubles a random variable, and the second adds two
1220  * independent random variables.
1221  *
1222  * A given random variable takes on a unique value that depends
1223  * deterministically on the pure variables of the function they belong
1224  * to, the identity of the function itself, and which definition of
1225  * the function it is used in. They are, however, shared across tuple
1226  * elements.
1227  *
1228  * This function vectorizes cleanly.
1229  */
1230 Expr random_float(Expr seed = Expr());
1231 
1232 /** Return a random variable representing a uniformly distributed
1233  * unsigned 32-bit integer. See \ref random_float. Vectorizes cleanly. */
1234 Expr random_uint(Expr seed = Expr());
1235 
1236 /** Return a random variable representing a uniformly distributed
1237  * 32-bit integer. See \ref random_float. Vectorizes cleanly. */
1238 Expr random_int(Expr seed = Expr());
1239 
1240 /** Create an Expr that prints out its value whenever it is
1241  * evaluated. It also prints out everything else in the arguments
1242  * list, separated by spaces. This can include string literals. */
1243 //@{
1244 Expr print(const std::vector<Expr> &values);
1245 
1246 template<typename... Args>
1247 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE Expr print(Expr a, Args &&...args) {
1248  std::vector<Expr> collected_args = {std::move(a)};
1249  Internal::collect_print_args(collected_args, std::forward<Args>(args)...);
1250  return print(collected_args);
1251 }
1252 //@}
1253 
1254 /** Create an Expr that prints whenever it is evaluated, provided that
1255  * the condition is true. */
1256 // @{
1257 Expr print_when(Expr condition, const std::vector<Expr> &values);
1258 
1259 template<typename... Args>
1260 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE Expr print_when(Expr condition, Expr a, Args &&...args) {
1261  std::vector<Expr> collected_args = {std::move(a)};
1262  Internal::collect_print_args(collected_args, std::forward<Args>(args)...);
1263  return print_when(std::move(condition), collected_args);
1264 }
1265 
1266 // @}
1267 
1268 /** Create an Expr that that guarantees a precondition.
1269  * If 'condition' is true, the return value is equal to the first Expr.
1270  * If 'condition' is false, halide_error() is called, and the return value
1271  * is arbitrary. Any additional arguments after the first Expr are stringified
1272  * and passed as a user-facing message to halide_error(), similar to print().
1273  *
1274  * Note that this essentially *always* inserts a runtime check into the
1275  * generated code (except when the condition can be proven at compile time);
1276  * as such, it should be avoided inside inner loops, except for debugging
1277  * or testing purposes. Note also that it does not vectorize cleanly (vector
1278  * values will be scalarized for the check).
1279  *
1280  * However, using this to make assertions about (say) input values
1281  * can be useful, both in terms of correctness and (potentially) in terms
1282  * of code generation, e.g.
1283  \code
1284  Param<int> p;
1285  Expr y = require(p > 0, p);
1286  \endcode
1287  * will allow the optimizer to assume positive, nonzero values for y.
1288  */
1289 // @{
1290 Expr require(Expr condition, const std::vector<Expr> &values);
1291 
1292 template<typename... Args>
1293 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE Expr require(Expr condition, Expr value, Args &&...args) {
1294  std::vector<Expr> collected_args = {std::move(value)};
1295  Internal::collect_print_args(collected_args, std::forward<Args>(args)...);
1296  return require(std::move(condition), collected_args);
1297 }
1298 // @}
1299 
1300 /** Return an undef value of the given type. Halide skips stores that
1301  * depend on undef values, so you can use this to mean "do not modify
1302  * this memory location". This is an escape hatch that can be used for
1303  * several things:
1304  *
1305  * You can define a reduction with no pure step, by setting the pure
1306  * step to undef. Do this only if you're confident that the update
1307  * steps are sufficient to correctly fill in the domain.
1308  *
1309  * For a tuple-valued reduction, you can write an update step that
1310  * only updates some tuple elements.
1311  *
1312  * You can define single-stage pipeline that only has update steps,
1313  * and depends on the values already in the output buffer.
1314  *
1315  * Use this feature with great caution, as you can use it to load from
1316  * uninitialized memory.
1317  */
1318 Expr undef(Type t);
1319 
1320 template<typename T>
1321 inline Expr undef() {
1322  return undef(type_of<T>());
1323 }
1324 
1325 /** Control the values used in the memoization cache key for memoize.
1326  * Normally parameters and other external dependencies are
1327  * automatically inferred and added to the cache key. The memoize_tag
1328  * operator allows computing one expression and using either the
1329  * computed value, or one or more other expressions in the cache key
1330  * instead of the parameter dependencies of the computation. The
1331  * single argument version is completely safe in that the cache key
1332  * will use the actual computed value -- it is difficult or imposible
1333  * to produce erroneous caching this way. The more-than-one argument
1334  * version allows generating cache keys that do not uniquely identify
1335  * the computation and thus can result in caching errors.
1336  *
1337  * A potential use for the single argument version is to handle a
1338  * floating-point parameter that is quantized to a small
1339  * integer. Mutliple values of the float will produce the same integer
1340  * and moving the caching to using the integer for the key is more
1341  * efficient.
1342  *
1343  * The main use for the more-than-one argument version is to provide
1344  * cache key information for Handles and ImageParams, which otherwise
1345  * are not allowed inside compute_cached operations. E.g. when passing
1346  * a group of parameters to an external array function via a Handle,
1347  * memoize_tag can be used to isolate the actual values used by that
1348  * computation. If an ImageParam is a constant image with a persistent
1349  * digest, memoize_tag can be used to key computations using that image
1350  * on the digest. */
1351 // @{
1352 template<typename... Args>
1353 inline HALIDE_NO_USER_CODE_INLINE Expr memoize_tag(Expr result, Args &&...args) {
1354  std::vector<Expr> collected_args{std::forward<Args>(args)...};
1355  return Internal::memoize_tag_helper(std::move(result), collected_args);
1356 }
1357 // @}
1358 
1359 /** Expressions tagged with this intrinsic are considered to be part
1360  * of the steady state of some loop with a nasty beginning and end
1361  * (e.g. a boundary condition). When Halide encounters likely
1362  * intrinsics, it splits the containing loop body into three, and
1363  * tries to simplify down all conditions that lead to the likely. For
1364  * example, given the expression: select(x < 1, bar, x > 10, bar,
1365  * likely(foo)), Halide will split the loop over x into portions where
1366  * x < 1, 1 <= x <= 10, and x > 10.
1367  *
1368  * You're unlikely to want to call this directly. You probably want to
1369  * use the boundary condition helpers in the BoundaryConditions
1370  * namespace instead.
1371  */
1372 Expr likely(Expr e);
1373 
1374 /** Equivalent to likely, but only triggers a loop partitioning if
1375  * found in an innermost loop. */
1376 Expr likely_if_innermost(Expr e);
1377 
1378 /** Cast an expression to the halide type corresponding to the C++
1379  * type T. As part of the cast, clamp to the minimum and maximum
1380  * values of the result type. */
1381 template<typename T>
1382 Expr saturating_cast(Expr e) {
1383  return saturating_cast(type_of<T>(), std::move(e));
1384 }
1385 
1386 /** Cast an expression to a new type, clamping to the minimum and
1387  * maximum values of the result type. */
1388 Expr saturating_cast(Type t, Expr e);
1389 
1390 /** Makes a best effort attempt to preserve IEEE floating-point
1391  * semantics in evaluating an expression. May not be implemented for
1392  * all backends. (E.g. it is difficult to do this for C++ code
1393  * generation as it depends on the compiler flags used to compile the
1394  * generated code. */
1395 Expr strict_float(Expr e);
1396 
1397 /** Create an Expr that that promises another Expr is clamped but do
1398  * not generate code to check the assertion or modify the value. No
1399  * attempt is made to prove the bound at compile time. (If it is
1400  * proved false as a result of something else, an error might be
1401  * generated, but it is also possible the compiler will crash.) The
1402  * promised bound is used in bounds inference so it will allow
1403  * satisfying bounds checks as well as possibly aiding optimization.
1404  *
1405  * unsafe_promise_clamped returns its first argument, the Expr 'value'
1406  *
1407  * This is a very easy way to make Halide generate erroneous code if
1408  * the bound promises is not kept. Use sparingly when there is no
1409  * other way to convey the information to the compiler and it is
1410  * required for a valuable optimization.
1411  *
1412  * Unsafe promises can be checked by turning on
1413  * Target::CheckUnsafePromises. This is intended for debugging only.
1414  */
1415 Expr unsafe_promise_clamped(const Expr &value, const Expr &min, const Expr &max);
1416 
1417 namespace Internal {
1418 /**
1419  * FOR INTERNAL USE ONLY.
1420  *
1421  * An entirely unchecked version of unsafe_promise_clamped, used
1422  * inside the compiler as an annotation of the known bounds of an Expr
1423  * when it has proved something is bounded and wants to record that
1424  * fact for later passes (notably bounds inference) to exploit. This
1425  * gets introduced by GuardWithIf tail strategies, because the bounds
1426  * machinery has a hard time exploiting if statement conditions.
1427  *
1428  * Unlike unsafe_promise_clamped, this expression is
1429  * context-dependent, because 'value' might be statically bounded at
1430  * some point in the IR (e.g. due to a containing if statement), but
1431  * not elsewhere.
1432  **/
1433 Expr promise_clamped(const Expr &value, const Expr &min, const Expr &max);
1434 } // namespace Internal
1435 
1436 /** Scatter and gather are used for update definition which must store
1437  * multiple values to distinct locations at the same time. The
1438  * multiple expressions on the right-hand-side are bundled together
1439  * into a "gather", which must match a "scatter" the the same number
1440  * of arguments on the left-hand-size. For example, to store the
1441  * values 1 and 2 to the locations (x, y, 3) and (x, y, 4),
1442  * respectively:
1443  *
1444 \code
1445 f(x, y, scatter(3, 4)) = gather(1, 2);
1446 \endcode
1447  *
1448  * The result of gather or scatter can be treated as an
1449  * expression. Any containing operations on it can be assumed to
1450  * distribute over the elements. If two gather expressions are
1451  * combined with an arithmetic operator (e.g. added), they combine
1452  * element-wise. The following example stores the values 2 * x, 2 * y,
1453  * and 2 * c to the locations (x + 1, y, c), (x, y + 3, c), and (x, y,
1454  * c + 2) respectively:
1455  *
1456 \code
1457 f(x + scatter(1, 0, 0), y + scatter(0, 3, 0), c + scatter(0, 0, 2)) = 2 * gather(x, y, c);
1458 \endcode
1459 *
1460 * Repeated values in the scatter cause multiple stores to the same
1461 * location. The stores happen in order from left to right, so the
1462 * rightmost value wins. The following code is equivalent to f(x) = 5
1463 *
1464 \code
1465 f(scatter(x, x)) = gather(3, 5);
1466 \endcode
1467 *
1468 * Gathers are most useful for algorithms which require in-place
1469 * swapping or permutation of multiple elements, or other kinds of
1470 * in-place mutations that require loading multiple inputs, doing some
1471 * operations to them jointly, then storing them again. The following
1472 * update definition swaps the values of f at locations 3 and 5 if an
1473 * input parameter p is true:
1474 *
1475 \code
1476 f(scatter(3, 5)) = f(select(p, gather(5, 3), gather(3, 5)));
1477 \endcode
1478 *
1479 * For more examples of the use of scatter and gather, see
1480 * test/correctness/multiple_scatter.cpp
1481 *
1482 * It is not currently possible to use scatter and gather to write an
1483 * update definition in which the *number* of values loaded or stored
1484 * varies, as the size of the scatter/gather packet must be fixed a
1485 * compile-time. A workaround is to make the unwanted extra operations
1486 * a redundant copy of the last operation, which will be
1487 * dead-code-eliminated by the compiler. For example, the following
1488 * update definition swaps the values at locations 3 and 5 when the
1489 * parameter p is true, and rotates the values at locations 1, 2, and 3
1490 * when it is false. The load from 3 and store to 5 will be redundantly
1491 * repeated:
1492 *
1493 \code
1494 f(select(p, scatter(3, 5, 5), scatter(1, 2, 3))) = f(select(p, gather(5, 3, 3), gather(2, 3, 1)));
1495 \endcode
1496 *
1497 * Note that in the p == true case, we redudantly load from 3 and write
1498 * to 5 twice.
1499 */
1500 //@{
1501 Expr scatter(const std::vector<Expr> &args);
1502 Expr gather(const std::vector<Expr> &args);
1503 
1504 template<typename... Args>
1505 Expr scatter(const Expr &e, Args &&...args) {
1506  return scatter({e, std::forward<Args>(args)...});
1507 }
1508 
1509 template<typename... Args>
1510 Expr gather(const Expr &e, Args &&...args) {
1511  return gather({e, std::forward<Args>(args)...});
1512 }
1513 // @}
1514 
1515 } // namespace Halide
1516
